abstract_summ: We describe our experiences with four COVID-19 cases at the polyclinics in January and February 2020.The high-risk department, longer duty hours, and suboptimal hand hygiene after contacting with patients were linked to COVID-19.During the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), healthcare workers (HCWs) caring for COVID-19 patient have to wear personal protective equipment (PPE) and are therefore susceptible to PPE-related adverse skin reactions.In a major London teaching hospital, 66/435 (15%) of COVID-19 inpatient cases between 2 March and 12 April 2020 were definitely or probably hospital-acquired, through varied transmission routes.In December 2019, a novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) emerged in Wuhan, China and spread globally, resulting in the first World Health Organization (WHO) classified pandemic in over a decade.1 As of April 2020, the United States (US) has the most confirmed COVID-19 cases worldwide, but public health interventions and testing availability have varied across the country.In the face of a potential pandemic of COVID-19, we suggest sustainable and scalable control measures developed based on lessons learned from SARS.Thirteen patients with coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) visited a university hospital in Seoul before recognizing their disease infections, causing contact with 184 hospital workers.
title_summ: Data-driven discovery of clinical routes for severity detection in COVID-19 pediatric casesCoronavirus disease (COVID-19) Community Testing Team in Scotland: A 14-day review, 6 to 20 February 2020Infection Control against COVID-19 in Departments of RadiologyTransference of COVID-19 patient in hospitals – A crucial phaseCharacteristics of Emergency Department Patients With COVID‐19 at a Single Site in Northern California: Clinical Observations and Public Health ImplicationsRisk Factors of Healthcare Workers with Corona Virus Disease 2019: A Retrospective Cohort Study in a Designated Hospital of Wuhan in ChinaAdverse skin reactions among healthcare workers during the coronavirus disease 2019 outbreak: a survey in Wuhan and its surrounding regionsDiagnosis and Management of First Case of COVID-19 in Canada: Lessons applied from SARSProtection of Healthcare Workers Against COVID-19 at a Large Teaching Hospital in Seoul, KoreaCOVID-19 infections among HCWs exposed to a patient with a delayed diagnosis of COVID-19Nosocomial transmission of COVID-19: a retrospective study of 66 hospital-acquired cases in a London teaching hospitalDelayed Recognition of Community Transmission of COVID-19 Resulting in Healthcare Worker Infections.COVID-19 in Singapore - a case series from primary care.
title_abstract_phrases: Characteristics of Emergency Department Patients With COVID‐19 at a Single Site in Northern California: Clinical Observations and Public Health ImplicationsIn December 2019, a novel coronavirus disease (COVID-19) emerged in Wuhan, China and spread globally, resulting in the first World Health Organization (WHO) classified pandemic in over a decade.1 As of April 2020, the United States (US) has the most confirmed COVID-19 cases worldwide, but public health interventions and testing availability have varied across the country.We describe our experiences with four COVID-19 cases at the polyclinics in January and February 2020.In a major London teaching hospital, 66/435 (15%) of COVID-19 inpatient cases between 2 March and 12 April 2020 were definitely or probably hospital-acquired, through varied transmission routes.Transference of COVID-19 patient in hospitals – A crucial phase• COVID-19 virus is primarily transmitted between humans through respiratory droplets and contact routes.The high-risk department, longer duty hours, and suboptimal hand hygiene after contacting with patients were linked to COVID-19.Adverse skin reactions among healthcare workers during the coronavirus disease 2019 outbreak: a survey in Wuhan and its surrounding regionsDuring the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19), healthcare workers (HCWs) caring for COVID-19 patient have to wear personal protective equipment (PPE) and are therefore susceptible to PPE-related adverse skin reactions.
